com.stormpath.sdk.challenge.sms

Class SmsChallenges

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.stormpath.sdk.challenge.Challenges
      • com.stormpath.sdk.challenge.sms.SmsChallenges

  • public final class SmsChallenges
extends Challenges
    Static utility/helper methods for working with SmsChallenge resources. Most methods are factory methods used for forming SmsChallenge-specific fluent DSL queries. For example: 
     Challenges.SMS.where(Challenges.SMS.status().eq(SmsChallengeStatus.WAITING_FOR_VALIDATION))
     .orderByStatus().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    or, if using static imports: 
     import static com.stormpath.sdk.challenge.Challenges.SMS.*;

 ...

 where(status().eq(SmsChallengeStatus.WAITING_FOR_VALIDATION))
     .orderByStatus().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    Since:
    1.1.0

      • Fields inherited from class com.stormpath.sdk.challenge.Challenges

      • getInstance

        public static final SmsChallenges getInstance()

      • criteria

        public static SmsChallengeCriteria criteria()
        Returns a new ChallengeCriteria instance to use to formulate a Challenge query.

        Note that it is usually more common to use the where method instead of this one as the where method usually lends to better readability. For example: 

         Challenges.criteria().add(Challenges.status().eq(ChallengeStatus.CREATED))...
        versus: 
         Challenges.where(Challenges.status().eq(ChallengeStatus.CREATED))...
        or when using static imports: 
         where(status().eq(ChallengeStatus.CREATED))
        While all three statements are equivalent, the second and third examples are shorter and probably more readable.
        Returns:
        a new ChallengeCriteria instance to use to formulate a Challenge query.

      • where

        public static SmsChallengeCriteria where(Criterion criterion)
        Creates a new SmsChallengeCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.
        Returns:
        a new SmsChallengeCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.

      • status

        public static EqualsExpressionFactory status()
        Creates a new EqualsExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Challenge status property, to be used to construct a status Criterion when building an ChallengeCriteria query. For example: 
         Challenges.SMS.where(Challenges.SMS.status().eq(SmsChallengeStatus.WAITING_FOR_VALIDATION);
        The above example invokes the returned factory's eq() method. This produces a status-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         ChallengeCriteria criteria = Challenges.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory statusExpressionFactory = Challenges.status();
 Criterion statusEqualsEnabled = statusExpressionFactory.eq(SmsChallengeStatus.CREATED);
 criteria.add(statusEqualsEnabled);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new status-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an ChallengeCriteria query.

      • newCreateRequestFor

        public static CreateChallengeRequestBuilder<SmsChallenge> newCreateRequestFor(SmsChallenge challenge)
        Creates a new CreateChallengeRequestBuilder instance reflecting the specified Challenge instance. The builder can be used to customize any creation request options as necessary.
        Parameters:
        challenge - the challenge to create a new record for within Stormpath
        Returns:
        a new CreateChallengeRequestBuilder instance reflecting the specified Challenge instance.
        Since:
        1.1.0
        See Also:
        Factor.createChallenge(CreateChallengeRequest)
